line.tr: Wenn die Nāgas die verkehrten Leidenschaften sehen [und] die Länder (verlassen), trocknen die Wasser aus, an Hunger sterben die Wesen, [und] dieser Jambudvīpa geht zugrunde.
When the Nāgas see the wrong passions [and] (leave) the lands, the waters dry up, the beings die of hunger, [and] this Jambudvīpa perishes.

line.tr: [Just] (as) earthenware bowls, no matter how many the potter fashions, all [have] breaking [as their] end, …
(So wie der Hirt seine) Kühe mit dem Stock bedroht [und] sie je zu ihren Hürden führt, auf solche Weise bedrohen Alter [und] Tod das Leben der Wesen [und] führen es seinem Ziel zu.

(Just like the herdsman) threatens (his) cows with a stick [and] leads them each to their paddocks, in such a way, old age [and] death threaten the life of the beings [and] lead it to its [ultimate] destination.
Wie der Bergstrom ... (nicht) umkehrt, so gehen die Leben vorüber und kehren nicht wieder um.
Like the mountain stream ... (does not) turn back, just so the lives go past and do not turn back again.
Es fragte der Buddha die Mönche: "Bei welchem Gespräch saßet ihr?"
The Buddha asked the monks: "What conversation were you sitting in?"
Sie fraßen sich nicht gegenseitig.
They did not eat each other.
Übel [ist] jetzt das Leben der Menschen, [aber] sie bringen nicht Lebensüberdruss hervor.
Evil now [is] the life of humans, [but] they do not call forth life-.weariness.
Unter dem Nyagrodhabaum hielt er [scil. Araṇemi] sich ständig auf, dort trug er den Schülern das Gesetz vor.
Under the Nyagrodha-tree he [i.e. Araṇemi] always stayed, there he recited the law to the students.
Vertraut nicht auf das Leben!
Do not trust in life!
[Just] as the thread stretched here: as much as it is woven with the woof, so much smaller it becomes. (cf : ii, 7)

Wie hier der aufgezogene Faden, wie oft er mit dem Einschlag verwebt wird, (so oft gering[er] wird), so [ist] hier das Leben der Menschen, wieviele auch leben, im Vergehen der Tage und Monate wird es hinterher nur abgeschnitten.

Like the taut thread here, [that,] as often as it is interwoven with the plait, (gets less as often), just so [is] the life of humans here, how ever many [there] live, in the passing of days and months it is but cut off afterwards.

[Just] as a being here, being led to be killed: as many steps as it takes to the killing place [lit. cemetery], with so many it (approaches)301 death. So the life of humans (is destroyed). (cf : ii, 7)
Das Leben [der Menschen ist] schwierig [und] nur gering, und es ist mit Leid verbunden, aber die Wesen merken [es] nicht.
Life [of humans is] difficult [and] only [of] little [value(?)], and it is accompanied by suffering, but the beings do not realise [this].
Wie der Stockstreich im Wasser vergeht in einem Augenblick, so vergeht das Leben der Menschen.
Just like a blow with a stick fades in the water within a moment, so fades human life.
Und plötzlich kommt Leid [und] Armut, schneidet die Hoffnung der Angehörigen ab [und] vernichtet alle Wünsche.
And suddenly there comes suffering [and] poverty, cuts off the hope of the relatives [and] destroys all wishes.

line.tr: Als Wagenfahrer fuhr der König Prasenajit. Da brach die Achse des Wagens, [und] die Speichen wurden auseinandergestreut.
As charioteer king Prasenajit was driving. Then the axle of the chariot broke, [and] the spokes were spread asunder.
Will I fall down from my great royal seat? Or will there be danger of my life?
If these were not there in the world, then the Buddha would not arise.
Um solche Nöte zu vertreiben, stehen hier die Alleswissenden auf.
In order to disperse such afflictions, here the omniscient ones rise.
Alt werden [auch] die Wagen des Königs, die sehr prachtvollen. Genau in derselben Weise (erreichen) auch die Körper das Alter.
[Even] the king's chariots, the very splendid ones, grow old. Exactly in the same way, the bodies also (reach) old age.
Wenn sie sorgfältig bewahrt [sind], bestehen die Wagen lange.
If they [are] carefully kept, the chariots exist [for a] long [time].
Er [scil. der Alleswissende] legte [sein] Obergewand ab [und] hielt [wtl. machte] [seinen] Rücken hoch zur Sonne [hin].
He [i.e. the Omniscient] took off [his] robe [and] held [lit. made] [his] back up to the sun.
Ananda saß auf den Knien, mit den beiden Handflächen streichelte(?) er den Körper des Buddha [und] rieb ihn.
Ananda sat on [his] knees, with both palms of [his] hands he stroked(?) the Buddha's body [and] rubbed it.

Es sprach zu dem Allwissenden Ānanda: "Es werden an dir gesehen [zeigen sich an dir], o Gott, das Anders-als-sonst-Sein [aller] fünf Sinnesorgane, Augen usw. Das Rissigsein der Haut [und] die Schlaffheit des Fleisches werden an dir gesehen [zeigen sich an dir]."

To the Omniscient Ānanda said: "On you, oh God, the being-different-than-usual of [all your] five sensory organs is seen, eyes etc. The crackedness of the skin [and] the limpness of the flesh is seen on you."
Shame be upon you, old age! You are of a mean kind [and] not noble.

The original manuscript is missing, but was an almost complete leaf in length, made up of various pieces. Damaged in several places, with the right hand end mising, creating a gap of about 1-4 syllables. Leaf number 29 was visible on the left margin.

The metre is 4x13 + 21 syllables in a 5/8 and 8/8/5 rhythm, but it is impossible to define individual verses with any certainty.

line.tr: Das Feuer (der Sinneslust) glüht in [seinem] Geist, der ganze Körper brennt ihm wie ein Feuerbrand(?) vor Leidenschaft.
The fire (of sensual pleasure) glows in [his] mind, his whole body burns like a firebrand with passion.
Der Gott der (Götter), der Buddha, der Schutz [und] die Zuflucht, befand sich bei Śrāvastī. Dort rief er die Schüler ...
The god of (gods), the Buddha, the shelter [and] the protection, tarried near Śrāvastī. There he summoned the students ...
(In) diesem (Geist) wirken drei Vorstellungen: eine der Sinneslust, die zweite aber des Übelwollens, die dritte die des Leidzufügens.
(Within) this (spirit) three notions operate: one of sensuality, the second of ill will, the third the one of inflicting suffering.
... die üblen Fehler der Vorstellungen, vor denen hütet euch!
... the evil flaws of the imaginations, of these beware!
If he is (anxious for the smothering of the thoughts, however), constantly practices a disgust [at the body], [is] constantly mindful [and] controlling all six senses in, ...
[Wenn] er ... ständig das Abscheu-Empfinden [gegenüber dem Körper] übt, ständig bedachtsam [und] alle sechs Sinnesfunktionen im Zaum haltend[wtl. gezügelt habend] [ist], ...

[If] he ... at all times practices the feeling of disgust [with regard to the body], [when he is] at all times deliberate [and] keeping all six sensory functions in check [lit. having disciplined], ...

comments.comment: On the recto side down to line 7 this contains the ending of part 2 of the Kāmavarga (II), i.e. strophes 37d-40 in a 4x25 syllable-metre (rhythm: 5/5/8/7). In line 8 the Tṛṣṇāvarga (III) begins, strophes 1-7c, in a 4x18 metre (rhythm: 7/7/4).

The original manuscript is missing, but was a piece of leaf patched together from various fragments, about the left half of leaf 41. In places the writing was attrited strongly, particularly in the top part.
